Leonardo da Vinci: Bringing Leonardo da Vinci back to life would be an incredible opportunity to learn from one of the greatest minds in history. He was a polymath who excelled in fields such as painting, sculpture, architecture, science, music, mathematics, engineering, literature, anatomy, geology, astronomy, botany, writing, history and cartography. He was also known for his curiosity and his ability to think outside the box. Imagine the knowledge and insights he could share with us today!

Cleopatra: Cleopatra was one of the most powerful and influential women in history. As the last pharaoh of Ancient Egypt, she ruled over a vast and prosperous kingdom. She was also known for her intelligence, charisma, and diplomatic skills. Bringing her back to life would be an opportunity to learn from her leadership and decision-making abilities.

Mahatma Gandhi: Gandhi was a political and spiritual leader who played a key role in India's struggle for independence from British rule. He is known for his philosophy of nonviolent resistance and his ability to inspire millions of people to work towards a common goal. Bringing him back to life would be an opportunity to learn from his leadership and his approach to conflict resolution.

Marie Curie: Marie Curie was a physicist and chemist who was the first woman to win a Nobel Prize and the first person to win two Nobel Prizes in different fields (Physics and Chemistry). She is known for her pioneering work on radioactivity and her contributions to the development of X-rays. Bringing her back to life would be an opportunity to learn from her scientific achievements and her perseverance in the face of discrimination.

Martin Luther King Jr.: Martin Luther King Jr. was a Baptist minister and activist who became the most visible spokesperson in the civil rights movement from 1954 until his assassination in 1968. He is known for his leadership in the advancement of civil rights using nonviolent civil disobedience based on his Christian beliefs. Bringing him back to life would be an opportunity to learn from his leadership and his approach to social justice.
